awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Efficient Bayesian Global Optimization with Applications to Deep Learning and Computer Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary objective of this research is to develop global optimization methods which will dramatically enhance the optimization efficiency in the studies of complex scientific problems. The research findings will significantly accelerate discoveries in numerous scientific disciplines involving artificial intelligence and numerical simulations such as mechanical engineering, energy, automated transportation, aerospace engineering, environmental science, and materials science. Integrated into the research is an education plan that emphasizes interdisciplinary training for a broad body of students and increasing participation from underrepresented groups. The PIs will recruit female students and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and actively involve them in this research. Research findings will be disseminated at conferences. Furthermore, research findings will also be integrated into PIs’ courses to have optimization and data analysis training for graduate and undergraduate students.  

This research focuses on Bayesian global optimization which refers to active learning strategies developed by stochastic process priors for the optimization of expensive "black box" functions. Motivated by the challenges emerged from global optimization in deep learning and computer experiments, two innovative Bayesian active learning methods will be developed which are applicable to problems with conditionally dependent inputs and non-Gaussian stochastic outputs. The first method will address an important but unresolved issue arising from the optimization of stochastic outputs in classification problems. The novelty lies in an expected improvement criterion developed based on a generalized Gaussian process which leads to a tractable objective function with an intuitive interpretation. The asymptotic convergence properties will be developed rigorously under the continuum-armed-bandit settings. The second method is based on a new correlation function for a branching and nested structure, which occurs commonly in practice. Sufficient conditions on the validity of the new correlation functions is expected to be derived and a new class of optimal initial designs will be systematically constructed. The innovative idea of automatic-tuning in deep learning by a rigorous Bayesian global optimization will shed light on new methodologies for the optimization of "black box" functions and inspire new research ideas in machine learning, optimization, and spatial statistics. Beyond the applications to computer vision and optimal controls in robotics, the design, modeling, and optimization strategies can open new avenues for studying complex optimization problems with expensive unknown functions and energize both theoretical and applied research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project made significant contributions to the fields of statistics, computational science, and applied interdisciplinary research, with outcomes that addressed both intellectual merit and broader societal impacts.

Intellectual Merit

This project advanced Bayesian surrogate modeling for complex systems, with applications to computer experiments and inverse problems. The development of new statistical methodologies for computer experiments and uncertainty quantification (UQ) improved the accuracy of predictions while minimizing computational costs. These surrogate models effectively combined data from simulations at different fidelity levels, addressing challenges in a range of fields including engineering, biology, and environmental science.

One notable achievement was the use of surrogate models for modeling biological processes, particularly carbon-concentrating mechanisms (CCMs) in extremophilic algae. This research offered new insights into how organisms optimize photosynthesis under extreme conditions. This work could inform future innovations in environmental biology and agriculture.

The project also applied Bayesian inverse methods to tackle functional inputs in inverse scattering problems, significantly improving accuracy in predicting material properties. This advancement in Gaussian process models has broad applications in physics and engineering, where accurate prediction of complex systems is crucial.

In public health, Bayesian modeling was used to develop COVID-19 transmission models, integrating environmental factors and government interventions to predict virus spread and offer decision-making tools for policymakers.

Beyond theoretical advancements, the project developed four R packages, making these methodologies accessible to the broader research community. These tools have been applied in various contexts, including epidemic modeling, environmental research, and engineering optimization.

 

Broader Impacts:

The project's broader impacts extended to both education and public outreach. Graduate-level courses incorporated the methodologies and findings, allowing students to engage with cutting-edge statistical models and computational techniques. A special topics course on Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) provided hands-on experience in applying UQ principles to real-world engineering problems.

The project also had a strong public outreach component, including participation in the MSU Science Festival, where children and visitors engaged with interactive STEM activities. These events helped foster interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields among young learners, inspiring future careers in science.

Graduate students also benefited significantly from the project, gaining research experience in areas such as machine learning and Bayesian optimization. These students contributed to the development of open-source software and presented their work at national conferences, building their professional skills and expanding their academic networks.

In summary, this project has made substantial contributions to both intellectual advancement and societal impact. The development of Bayesian surrogate modeling, the creation of educational tools, and public outreach efforts have all played a role in advancing knowledge while fostering the next generation of researchers and innovators.
